Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Seperation... Also if the private key for a KMD notary node  is imported into a thrid party coin, they could get the KMD notary node keys... and that would be game over if they were a bad actor, or were over taken by a bad actor.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Using a seperate keys solves this, BUT likley all 3rd party coins wouls till use the same key.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: If a project wanted ultimate security they would need their own nodes.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: There is no reason to have to have 64 of them though, you could use less to save on costs. Also just notarizing one coin to KMD, is very lean on resource.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: We are easily doing 10 coins on STAKED with 4 thread, 8GB RAM VPS on VULTR.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: So for a single coin, you could use somehting very small... as long as you have enough ram/swap to build the coins deamons and sync the chain. Iguana itself is very low on recource, only RAM and SSD is required.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Well yes and no... You would likely need a single perso to be trained up, but the STAKED stuff is extremly easy to use, not having to worry about updates for extra coins etc.... its almsot a set and forget thing, with some kind of notification if out of utxo, or iguana stopped working, login and restart it or send some funds. thats just about it.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
@joey thanks for dropping by for discussion 😃 

Running your own notaries as per #private-staked may be an option, it increases delay to btc level security if notarizing to kmd is a step involved as well (which I still recommend).  On one hand running your own notaries could be viewed as “centralized” without a similar voting process etc. but that would be something for FLO ecosystem to work out.  Each app could run some servers, as more apps use FLO, more nodes.  Keep in mind 64 nodes connecting to each other is 4k connections, more would be a new set of problems.

The dPoW has no interference w the apps reward systems on FLO.  If offering the users an opportunity to participate in security, what level of participation?  NNs mark checkpoints in a very expensive system.  FLO users would participate in the NN process, it would be completely insecure for your node to not be operated by a v.small team of trusted ppl.

Further, once engaged in the Komodo community, getting votes from creating ecosystem collaboration would be something the community looks for.  The notary voting is open to anyone, it is a friendly competitive and collaborative effort once elected, but certainly not something that can really be expected to be involved with, with no prior Komodo collaboration or input as there is no history that would appeal to community voters.

Either way, if you’ve got ideas with DEX and the rest of the tech, might see you around more in the future 👍

Author: Alright#0419
Content: A coin could run their own notaries, but there is *a lot* of work in getting that setup. They'd need to consider the server costs, man hours of maintaining each, maintaining the network itself, cost of notarization itself, politics behind who can/can't be a notary, how to incentivize notaries to have good up time and not collude

Author: Alright#0419
Content: none of that sounds that bad until you start doing, trust me 😂

Author: Alright#0419
Content: it'd be a good solution for trusted setups, but keeping it more decentralized than KMD's notaries is close to impossible

Author: Alright#0419
Content: I have a crazy amount of respect for whoever setup the initial network. Was a *very* hard task

Author: noon e#5424
Content: For some time now wanted to ask JL777 a question. Was the decision of KMD apr cap switched from yearly to monthly yours? Or were there some kind of public vote implemented. I mean, that's a major change to the blockchain protocol. For me personally that made a lot of complications. I keep everything paper-wallet style. It's now a monthly headache for me with generating new addresses, printing, resyncing, deleting and all that long time consuming stuff I was hoping to avoid with KMD. I do what I need to do, I understand, but was that decision voted? Thanks.

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content:
The reason was that this reward should be given to people who make an effort and help KMD.
More transactions on the network increase the value of the network -> increase in price and more z transactions increase the privacy.
On the possitive side this new 31 Days cap forces you to get 5.11% Rewads per years and not 'only' 5%
So it is possible ( not to say this will happen any time soon or ever ) that in the future maybe you will only get rewards if you participate in a z transaction.
As all the Notary Nodes Updated to the new code base, the decision was accepted by them.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: tbh, the 1 million block update also removed the free for all, which made running anotary node much easier, so we kind of had to accept the rewards change aswell. 😕

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Not that i think its a bad thing.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I like the change personally.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: It stops whales just buying and holding and getting more coins than active users.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @noon e FYI if you have UTXOs from before block 1M, they earn interest from pre-block-1M rules, i.e. no 31 day cap

Author: Fai#0350
Content:
Hi @jl777c  Is there a plan for Komodo to get more community adoption and subsequently end-user adoption? 

For the former, I feel that VeChain have masternodes and x-nodes who can join in on the community ICO round (prior to public round). So it's  not just private VC vs public fundraising. 

For the latter, it is based on the assumption that ICO/dICO is a good way to get more use cases and users onto the Komodo platform by way of the coins/token gamification or incentives and dApps.

Author: Privatoshi#9487
Content:
@jl777c I am seeking a small bit of advice. I have little to no, programming experience. But I do have a good foundation in computer networking & security--enough to pass a Cisco CCNA cert exam. And, at the moment, I'm spending most of my time in the Verus discord. However I do recognize most all of the Komodo dev team, from researching various cryptocurrencies--or probably just because you are one hell of a talented group of guys--and you tend to value privacy. I am different. I appreciate the developers.
So,  I want to get into programming and, for some odd reason, I want to work with crypto wallets--desktop & mobile. I really enjoy crypto & I was lucky to read the BTC white paper in '11 & I agree with the core argument of the right to individual privacy and the right for financial fair play, at any level. 
Like I mentioned, I'm very happy to be a part of the Verus community & to see what Mike Tout., and the Verus dev team has accomplished, so far. I'm sure that between Komodo and Verus-- you'll probably find the most talented group of developers, in all of cryptocurrency. So for me, to spend time in the Verus discord and Komodo discord, and to read some of the work you guys are doing in Pirate channel in the Komodo channel or Staked, I think it is lol--it made me think what a waste it would be to just not ask, for a piece of advice. Because I want to be involved in cryptocurrency, on the developing side. 

In as short or as long, as you want to answer--what do you think would be the best first step to take? I did jump right into networking & that worked out. But I also understand that a good first step into anything, is so beneficial. I understand that guys ask questions like this, all of the time, and they probably bullshit 99 percent of the time. If you don't have time to answer, it's not a big deal, I don't take it personal. My plan, as of now, is to start with C, and spending time in the Verus GitHub--trying to look and pick up on, what I can.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @Privatoshi best way to learn how something works is to break it IMO

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Just try things no one ever expected someone to do, and you'll start finding bugs

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Thats the best way. I learnt most of my skills but just reading code, then trying to break said code, until i understood how it works. You will find things that nobdy else thaught of looking for. Because they read documentation and followed instructions. Those things help, but ignoring them and just trying things by trial and error are far more productive, if you want to undestand the how and why something works, not just how to use it.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Once you know how and why something works, then you can change how or why it works to do something else.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: test

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in order to be a coder, you need to be able to find the vast majority of your own bugs

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but, like riding a bicycle, there is not anything you can read to magically know how to find bugs

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just do it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: read the docs, understand what the rpc calls are supposed to do and then find when it doesnt behave right

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is is first step. finding a possible bug

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then isolate it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: get the minimal sequence needed to duplicate the bug reliably

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at this point you can describe the bug in detail, how to reproduce it quickly and the dev will be able to fix it quickly

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I am very good at testing as I spend about half my time testing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: by the time I feel my code is ready for others to test, there are still bugs, but usually really easy to find and fix ones or really hard to reproduce ones

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: now, once you are able to test effectively. then coding becomes much easier as you are always thinking what sorts of bugs will this have, how can i find them and isolate them, while you are coding. And you dont bother coding something that cant be tested, saving a lot of wasted time. so many devs have no clue about testing they release code that just cant be debugged

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i like to code by making one change at a time.
